body: It should probably be noted that I tested this locally on my machine using `wwtd` as well, and it's happening there too.
Initially I tried reproducing this with `wwtd` but couldn't get it to happen. However after running `bundle update` I could get it to occur with a normal `rake test`
As well, `rspec spec/unit/comments_spec.rb` also raises the error.

Luckily I copied my Gemfile.lock beforehand:

``` sh
$ diff Gemfile.lock.old Gemfile.lock
103c103
<     cucumber (1.3.8)
---
>     cucumber (1.3.9)
106c106
<       gherkin (~> 2.12.1)
---
>       gherkin (~> 2.12)
111c111
<     devise (3.1.1)
---
>     devise (3.2.0)
173c173
<     parallel_tests (0.16.2)
---
>     parallel_tests (0.16.3)
204c204
<     ransack (1.0.0)
---
>     ransack (1.1.0)
223c223
<     rspec-expectations (2.14.3)
---
>     rspec-expectations (2.14.4)
```

I'm not sure why any of those would cause this problem though...

I did a bit of debugging, and it looks like the [line where we load AA::Comments](https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/blob/98885e34720de4fac0786e9b1d1a2889ccae336d/lib/active_admin.rb#L121) doesn't get run because `ActiveRecord` isn't yet loaded.
Good thinking. I suspect it's Cucumber. It started happening before rspec-expectations and devise were released yesterday.
Seeing how `rspec spec/unit/comments_spec.rb` gets the exception, could Cucumber really be at fault?
Hmm, I'm going through the list now, and it looks like it's Ransack that's causing the problem... How is that even possible?
Ahh... looks like it was https://github.com/ernie/ransack/commit/ff617be5730663174a1ebf5f9bb6a225e7306ece. It's all your fault @johnnyshields :P

This is confusing. Our tests [load Rails](https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/blob/98885e34720de4fac0786e9b1d1a2889ccae336d/spec/spec_helper.rb#L94); is that not enough to also load `ActiveRecord`?

Apparently not:

``` irb
>> require 'rails'
 => true 
>> ActiveRecord
NameError: uninitialized constant ActiveRecord
```
So what's the best way to solve this? Should we just `require 'rails/all'`?

issue.title: Devise tests failing

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
After resolving #2664, this happened:
![screen shot 2013-11-07 at 9 30 18 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/688886/1498170/4af1bfc4-4826-11e3-895e-4cf449328aa4.png)
It very likely has to do with Devise 3.2.0 which was recently released.

issue.title: Comments spec failing due to ActiveRecord::Comment not found

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body: comments_spec.rb needs an explicit require for the AR comments plugin

body: @seanlinsley yes, this is expected behavior--you now have to require ActiveRecord yourself, and you no longer depend on some obscure gem dependency to do it for you!

For Mongoid users, the trouble is that AA forces us to load the bulky AR library when we have no intention of using it. :smirk:

Speaking of which, try Mongoid / MongoDB on your next project. You'll never go back to AR / SQL

I don't know; Postgres has a really nice set of features. Why would I choose MongoDB over Postgres?

But anyway I definitely agree that AA should be ORM agnostic.

Postgres does have nice features, but MongoDB really takes it to a new level. In general I find MongoDB's "Document DB" to be much closer to how objects are represented in Ruby themselves, e.g. support for hash and array structures, so you end up thinking much less about how to "stuff" an object into a SQL box then pull it out again. In other words, all the magic that AR does is not really needed in the first place in the Mongo world.
